hints.content:
$\blueD{4} \times (\maroonD{2} \times \greenD{7})$ can represent $\blueD{4}$ groups of $\maroonD{2}$ groups of $\greenD{7}$.

![4 groups of 2 groups of 7 dots](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/92616521209821823ead880db20021ac9d2fda2b)

How can we complete $(\blueD{4} \times{\maroonD{2}})\times {\greenD{?}}$ to get the same total?

We can think of $(\blueD{4} \times{\maroonD{2}})\times \greenD{{?}}$ as $(\blueD{4} \times {\maroonD{2}})$ groups of $\greenD{{?}}$.   

![The same dots in 8 groups of 7. The groups are in 4 columns with 2 groups per column](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/dfdbc48d9e1c8d2762575e718e6191b5d6ed339a)

There are $\purpleC{8}$ groups of $\greenD{7}$, which equals $(\blueD{4} \times {\maroonD{2}})$ groups of $\greenD{7}$.

We can change the grouping of the factors without changing the total.  

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
As long as we're only multiplying, we can group the factors in any way without changing the total product.

We call that the **associative property of multiplication**.

It does *not* work when we mix multiplication with other operations like addition.

For example:

$\begin{align}
2+(3 \times 4) &\neq (2 + 3) \times 4\\\\
2+12 &\neq 5 \times 4\\\\
14 &\neq 20
\end{align}$
